Entry.2: Tooth filled by Military Dentist. Signed for 4 Barrack’s damages
Entry.3: Cabled Mother address 35th Bn Wrote home
Entry.4: Entrained 10.40am & arrived S/Hampton Wharf 12.15pm. Embarked on"Antrim" 5.15pm – am alongside the"Aquetania". Saw shells 6" being loaded for Italy & R.G.A. en route to Egypt. left wharf 7.15pm. Paid 2/6 & got hammock in good position on boat.
Entry.5:
Very rough coming across Channel but was not sick. Up 6.30am & disembarked 7.30am at Le Havre. Marched about 4 miles to Base Camp arriving 11am. Bully beef Army biscuits for dinner

Biscuits & Bully Beef for tea.
Entry.6: Fourteen sleeping in tent. Reveille 5.15am. Breakfast of bacon Tinned Beans bread & jam at 6.30am. Fall in 8am. Issued with Steel Helmets, WP sheet, Gas helmet & Rifle Oil. Through Tear Gas test 10.30am & Helmets adjusted to proper size. 2pm issued with rifles & bayonets then gave my rifle good cleaning. After tea went to 5th Division Camp & sent ppcards to Australia.
Entry.7: Church Parade at 2nd Divn Camp. After dinner went down to Le Havre for couple of hours. Got great view of the place from big hill which we crossed. Rained heavily & got wet through. Wrote to Shielsy & Uncle Fred. Rained almost all night.
Entry.8:
reveille 5am. Marched one

mile to building on top of hill. Had Gas lecture. Dinner out there. Raining heavily all morning so came back 2pm.
Entry.9: Wet nearly all day. Paid £1-9-4 (40 francs) – making total debits £30-10-3
Entry.10: Rained heavily morning. Bull ring at 10.30am & bayonet & Bombing
Entry.11: Warned for draft for front. In tents all day – rained slightly. Sent ppcards to England & Australia.
Entry.12: Fall in 7.30am full marching order. Marched to Havre Stn to a troop train coming 11.45am. Left 4.30pm. Travelled via Yvetot, Motteville, Bosc-le-Hard, Carine, Serqueux, Abbeville, Conchil-le-Temple, St Josse, Etaples, Hesdigneul, Boulogne, Tentelleries, Wimereux, St Omer, Arques, Wizernes, Lumbres.
Entry.13:
Left train at Lumbres 3.30pm, Raining heavily. Marched ½ mile to a 

paddock alongside Rfct Orderly Room & took off packs. Issued with 1 blanket & then marched 7 kilometres to the village of Wizernes to billets & with 24 others was billeted in a farmer’s shed by 10.30pm. Issued with cup of tea each.
Entry.14: Slept soundly – 3 of us in 1 bed & rose 8am. Breakfast then shaved. Billet is wooden framework filled in with sand and straw plaster. Had good feed blackberries. Tasted green walnuts for first time – rather pleasant to taste.
Entry.15: Fine day. Inspected by Colonel then summoned to new billet – 8 of us in a stable. Squad drill etc in afternoon. Heard gun-fire all last night like muffled thunder & all during the day as wind changed. Saw several aeroplanes & an observation balloon.
Entry.16: Fine sunshine. Practising skirmishing in fields all day. Saw anti-aircraft shells exploding high up in air over the line. Very heavy smoke & haze all along the line i.e 40 miles away. Band played near village church after tea XX washed shirt & u/pants & Hdcfs in the creek near billet. Heard Fritz aeroplane brought down near Lumbres on Sunday – had been raiding Boulogne.
Entry.17: Muster parade 9.30am then bathing parade almost 3 miles away. Arrived back 4pm having lunch out there. Several new planes flying about.
Entry.18: Heavy thunderstorm during night. Heard 2 horses killed by lightening. Out practising skirmishing all day. Very hot. Guns still audible in distance. Had 2 glasses wine before going to bed.
Entry.19: On skirmishing stunt all day having lunch out on field. After tea went out for blackberries.
Entry.20: Battalion sports all day. Left just after dinner for billets & washed hdcfs then bathed in stream alongside billet. Heard going to line on Tuesday. Few more casuals arrived from Havre. Heavy fog til 9am. Went blackberrying after tea.
Entry.21: – beautiful sunshine, not a cloud to be seen. On ½ rations today. Numbers of aeroplanes about. 2pm walked into Lumbres with Ashwood. Bought maps of France in there, then had steak & eggs for tea – cost 3 francs. Left 6pm & arrived back 7.30pm. Sent ppcards to Australia & England in green envelope also with 2 whiz-bangs.
Entry.22:
Lewis Gun all day.

19/9/17 Very cloudy early on but turned out nice sunshine. Still ½ rations. Blackberrying after tea with Andy. Received letters from Uncle Charlie, & C’wealth Bank
Entry.23: Very cold night but beautiful sunshine morning. On Lewis gun all day. Had drink rum at estaminet at dinner time. Squadron of aeroplanes exercising overhead in morning. After tea more blackberries then walked to village of Cantmerle for stroll.
Entry.24: Lewis gun morning only. Received letter from Aunt Sarah dated 27/6/17. Holiday in afternoon so strolled about 3 miles through Cantemerle & had blackberries. After tea battalion went on night stunt but Lewis Gunners did not go.
Entry.25: Route march with full packs thro’ Fondebecques, Elnes, Ouve, & back to Wismes. Distance about 16 kilometres. Turned fairly cold. Wrote to Aunt Sara
Entry.26: Very cloudy. On Lewis gun in morning. After dinner on stunt out past Drionville. After tea went blackberrying with Andy.
Entry.27: Rained during night & came on to my bunk. Very muggy. Out with Lewis Guns. Received letter from Uncle Charlie. Bathed & washed clothes in afternoon as was fine. After tea went blackberrying with Andy. Mess Orderly today.
Entry.28:
Cloudy. After dinner went to Lumbres with Andy. Tried every shop in town for book of Anglo-French phrases but unsuccessful. Had coffee

& biscuits in shop, drank beer each in an estaminet & then steak & eggs at restaurant. Left 7pm & arrived back 8.10pm. Received 2 letters from Muriel & 1 from Mrs Brown. Warned for trip to coast tomorrow for surf bathing. Turned out very fine in afternoon. Saw Chinese Coolies & Portuguese troops in Lumbres
Entry.29:
Reveille 5am & left 9am in 3 ton motor lorries for the coast. Travelled via Drionville, Senlecques, Desvres, Wirwignes, Cremarest, & Marquise to Tardinghen near Cape Gris-Nez arriving 12.30pm. After lunch walked to Wissant & saw remains of German submarine recently stranded there.

Bought p/card views of town & had cup of black coffee – very nice. Coming on cloudy again. Wissant has very pretty villas facing the sea. Distinctly saw English coast of Dover from top of hill just before arriving, also couple of destroyers in the strait. Roman camp was situated at Wissant in ancient times. Where we are camped is a motor presented to Red Cross by Wilcannia. After tea strolled to Tardinghen & had drink of beer.
Entry.30: Light rain all morning spoiling the trip. Started back 2pm arriving 6.45pm drizzly rain all the way. Came back same route as we went.
Entry.31:
Fine day. Marched 5 kilos to a gas lecture & went through various forms gas attacks

with real gas. Afternoon off. Wrote to Mother, Uncle Charlie & Mrs Brown. Paid today. Also wrote to Essie Ingles & Uncle Will.
Entry.32: Rained good deal in night. On Lewis gun in morning coming back 11.30am. Btn drill in afternoon back 4.20pm. Blackberrying after tea.
Entry.33: Much cooler though fine. Out all day on Battalion drill & a stunt. Fairly cold night.
Entry.34: Reveille 6.15am & breakfast 7am. Marched 2 miles & whole division was reviewed by Sir Douglas Haig near Drionville. After dinner four of us went blackberrying also had a feed raw turnips.
Entry.35:
Guns audible in distance last 2 days. Numbers of aeroplanes flying about.

Went into Lumbres with Andy & had 4 eggs for tea – cost of 4 cent each. Heard that 34th Btn received orders to go to Ypres on Tuesday, also whole division probably moving this week. Came back via St Pierre.

24/9/17 Reveille 6am, breakfast 6.30am & moved off to brigade attack practice about 5 kilos away. Generals Godley (2nd Anzac Army Corps) & Monash were present also 2 or 3 Brigadier Generals turned out nice sunshiney day. On way to stunt passed an English motor transport for heavy artillery. It had several heavy gun mountings drawn by caterpillars also one 12 inch howitzer. Received letter from Mum dated July 8th.

Food very scanty today.
Entry.36: Heard there was a big riot in Etaples a fortnight ago – 1 redcap & 1 Scot were killed. Paraded full marching order & warned to move off early tomorrow morning. List of shortages etc also taken. Issued with pair of new boots size
Entry.38: Up 4am & marched out 7.15am – marched via Lumbres, Hallines, Wizernes, Blendecques to Ecques almost 15 or 16 miles arriving at 4.15pm. Had several hats on road. NZ Corps were also on same road. Are on top of hill at Ecques & have splendid view towards Lens district.
Entry.39:
Up 4am & started 6am via Pont-Asquins, Embellingham, St Pierre-Cappel, St Sylvestre-Cappel,

to couple kilos beyond Eecke. Had to bivouac in open as our platoon lost toss for the only billet available. Heard heavy gunfire all night. Could see red glow of shell fire also various aeroplane lights & anti-aircraft & shrapnel shells exploding in air. Saw about 20 aeroplanes go over toward German lines after dark.

28/9/17 Turned very cold in night & heavy fog in morning. Nice fine sunshine. Up 7am breakfast 7.20 & marched off 8.30 am. Went via Steenvoorde to near Winnezeelee (couple of miles from Belgian territory) to a camp

consisting of tents. Camp is about 18 or 20 miles from firing line. Have been placed on reserve of Lewis Gunners so will miss this stunt unless others become casualties. After tea went into Winnezeele with Andy & had drink each. Streets packed with men of 1st &
Entry.40: divisions. Sent Ppcards of Wissant to Australia.
Entry.41:
Heavy gunfire audible all night, especially at about 5am. Fairly cold night. Cloudy. Up 7.30am breakfast 8am. Boot parade 11am & had couple nails in my boots knocked out. No other parades but had band playing. Sharpened my bayonet. Some of the Lewis gunners & Snipers left for trenches after dinner,

also most of 34th battalion. On fatigue after dinner picking up papers & rubbish etc. Couple of German aeroplanes dropped bombs near camp after tea. After tea went into Winnezeele.
Entry.42: Very cold night. Up 6.30am & then all busy getting ready & packing up for the line. Received 2 letters from home dated 11/3/17 &
Entry.43: also 2 parcels & 1 letter from Uncle Will. All men not going to line marched out, full packs, about 12 noon & marching around the outskirts of Steenvoorde & St Sylvestre-Cappel arrived 5.15pm at Morbeck just outside Hazebrouck through which we marched. Hazebrouck is a very fine town with good buildings – has a big square right in centre of city.
Entry.44:
Cold all night. Heavy fog early in morning. Nice fine sunshine. Paraded 9.30am after roll called

& all sorted out informed have to be barrack room orderlies for a time – i.e. shave & clean boots every day etc. 

Dismissed 11.15am & shaved & cleaned rifles. Have to manage best we can for tucker today. All other btns are OK for food except us. No transport was sent back with us last night. Huns dropped bombs near Hazebrouck so there was a great clatter with anti-aircraft shells & the bombs. Our btn was to go into line near Ypres last night & hop over early this morning. After tea went into Hazebrouck with Bradley & had steak eggs & chips costing 2 francs 6 each. Windows are broken everywhere by bomb concussion & several places badly damaged. Saw 2 anti aircraft guns on road on way in.

Bought Anglo-French dictionary 3 francs.
Entry.45: Night not quite so cold. Had little drill both morning & afternoon. Day fairly warm. Pay books collected preparatory to pay. After tea went into Morbecque & bought loaf of bread 1 franc & 3. Had scare this afternoon an aeroplane passed over & they thought was a Fritz so all had to take cover under hedges & trees. Turned out to be an English plane & the bombs were at our own bombing school.
Entry.46: Not nearly as cold in night – rained a good deal too. Muster parade in morning & little drill during day. After tea in Morbecque picquet with 11 others & a 36th Sergt. He shouted all hands beers, biscuits & pears. Got back about 10.15pm.
Entry.47:
Short route

march in morning then paid. Rained during night & still threatening. A trainload of 12 tanks passed after dinner proceeding towards line. After tea went into Hazebrouck with a N. Zealander & looked around the place. Bought books of views of town.
Entry.48: Rained heavily last night & very cold this morning. Heard our boys hopped over yesterday morning & took all objectives. Route march with drill order all morning. Rained heavily dinner time. Little dull in afternoon. After tea went into Hazebrouck & had Steak & Eggs cost 2fr 9.
Entry.49:
Very cold last night & this morning. Packed off to march back to Winnezeele but cancelled temporarily

on account of rain. Set out about 11am with full packs and blankets (in drizzling cold rain) for Winnezeele & arrived there about 5pm – distance 11 miles. Met all the other chaps back from the line. Considering everything they had very few casualties. Ewing & MacKay were blown to pieces with shells. After tea went into Winnezeele with Andy & Burrell & met some of the old 62nd chaps who have joined 13 Btn
Entry.50:
– Very cold all night but slept well. Plenty of mud about the camp. Issued with woollen undershirt. After dinner walked to Le Rivelt with Andy & K Fourell & had meal of eggs, also bought bread. Rained heavily all afternoon.

After tea went to an estaminet for a couple of hours with 3 others.
Entry.51: Very cold all night but morning fine. Received letter from Uncle Will & parcel from F. Lasseters. Went to Le Rivelt again for bread & met Dick Luscombe. Had some tea with him & stopped about an hour. Selected in Lewis Gun team for hop-over in couple days. Did not go out after tea on account of heavy rain.
Entry.52:
Had parade 9.30am to clean up ammunition & equipment. Very strong cold wind blowing. Received letter from Muriel dated 21/7/17. Cleaned up Lewis Gun ammunition ready for the live also the gun. Wrote to Muriel, Aunt Sara & Uncle Fred

Went down town and bought some bread for the tent.
Entry.53:
Cold all last night. Up 5.30am & paraded 7.15am full marching order but did not move out. Left 1pm & marched 1½ miles where we all got into old motor buses bound for Ypres. Rained all morning but afternoon nice & fine though cold. Travelled via Steenwoorde, Abeele & outskirts of Poperinge to Ypres arriving 6pm. Marched couple miles through Ypres & across paddocks full of shell holes mud & slush up to ankles & got lost in so doing & therefore had to bivouac in open for the night & of course it rained. Had to go to bed without any tea as cookers also got lost. Considering

all the difficulties I slept very well having on all clothes boots etc – feet were cold all night though.
Entry.54:
Have been busy drying blankets etc. Then we rigged up a tent & cleaned rifles, bayonets, Lewis guns etc. Fell in 6pm for inspection then had stew & at 6.45pm moved off to front line in single file. I started off with 4 panniers of ammunition for Lewis Gun but soon broke down with its weight so Henry (the officer) took 2 panniers & Andy 2. About ½ hr after took 2 off Andy & took them right into action. Had very rough march in dawn up

amongst shell holes & along smashed up rail embankments & under shell fire for about 2 miles but there were no casualties.
Entry.55:
Just a year today since went into camp at Dubbo. Marched all night with very few spells so all hands were very fatigued. Arrived front line 5.15am & 5.25 barrage started & we hopped over. Ground was very muddy & shell holes everywhere so that walking with our load was extremely difficult. Eventually arrived at 1st objective with very few casualties & were there held up

for good time by machine guns, snipers & shell fire & men then fell very quickly. I lost the Lewis Gun team but when all were held up found the No1 (Tom Eddy) again – all the others were either casualties or lost. Tom wounded in wrist binding up trench so he made me No1 & I dumped my rifle & took his revolver. After being stuck up about an hour we advanced but I could not keep up with my load & gradually got left behind & kept falling over in mud with fatigue. Fritz started heavily shelling

about where I fell over last so I got into a shell hole with couple others & from this point everything is a blank to me & I think I got shell shock. I know shells were falling almost on edge of shell hole but still had not felt any fear or been nervy up to this point. That concussion of a shell outed me for a time anyhow everything was a blank till I came to my senses fairly close to Ypres near a lake & some naval guns – had walked 

several miles. Had also lost all my equipment & the Lewis Gun & revolver. I then looked around for our camp as too fatigued to go back to the line then, & then walked 3 or 4 miles pretty well all around Ypres trying to find it. I struck some Victorians from 60th Btn & they gave me a good feed of stew & bread & jam as was famished with hunger & cold & wet through with rain having lost overcoat waterproofs everything. I eventually found the camp about 8pm

& turned in (but was looking around about ½ hour finding the tent) & slept like a top.
Entry.56: During the night Fritz shelled the camp but only damaged one tent – no casualties. One big shell fell 20 yds from our tent & splashed it with mud etc. Got up 8.30am & had good breakfast & have since been trying to dry some of my clothes but almost impossible on account of the rain. A heavy thunderstorm splashed over & heavy hail fell. Very cold all day.
Entry.57: On working party to front line but 9 of us only got ½ way as all too fatigued to keep up. Were trying to get to front but Fritz started heavily shelling our track so had to turn back. Had lunch there among some old dugouts (were there were numbers of dead & horrible stinks) then did 2 hours work on the railway line with the Tommies. Got back at 4.30pm just in time for tea feeling terribly tired & worn out. Track was very heavy with mud all way out. Went bed 6pm & slept well.
Entry.58: All fit men in camp sent to front line but 28 of us went on sick parade into Ypres. Away all morning & saw the ruins of the place including the Cloth Hall. After dinner issued with old rusty rifles & putting an afternoon cleaning them up. Went to bed about 6pm.
Entry.59:
Were busy cleaning rifles ready for an inspection when Fritz started shelling the camp. In 33rd btn 2 killed & 2 wounded & in 35th (our btn) the pay Sergt was blown to pieces. All men were ordered to scatter & at 10.30am orders came

to shift camp. We packed up & struck tents & at 3pm marched off through Ypres to a place almost 2 miles west of it arriving 6pm. Had to pitch tents in the dark & after a cup of tea & biscuits went to bed about 8pm feeling very cold. Was also drizzling rain. Slept very well.
Entry.60:
Nice fine day, first for several days. Shaved first time for about 10 days. Then walked to 2nd Divisional Canteen & bought chocolates & biscuits. Washed towel & hdcfs & dryed sox. Saw a German aeroplane brought down in flames this morning by our airmen. Saw the Germans body. Just met a 

chap from
Entry.61:
btn & he told me Reg N had been killed at Polygon Wood on about Sep 27th. He was first of all wounded then a shell came along & blew him to pieces. Last Sunday received letters from Muriel, Mrs Nancarrow, Minnie Lusc, Guild, Uncle Harry & Amanda.

18/10/17 Could not get to sleep for a long time on account of the vermin crawling about & going to bed too early viz 5.30pm. Received change underclothes & sox so had cold bath in creek alongside camp & changed. Went to canteen in afternoon & bought some chocolate. Some of the chaps arrived

back from front line looking dead beat. Each was given a tot of rum. After tea went for a walk almost 1 mile out. Camps are situated everywhere.
Entry.62:
Breakfast 8.30am. Received letters from Uncle Fred & Aunt Sara. In morning party of us went to Vlamertinge for hot showers. Enjoyed it immensely. Rained all afternoon so could not get out. Went to bed 5.30pm.

20/10/17 Received letter from Uncle Charlie. Wrote to Mrs N.., Minnie Lusc & Uncle Harry. Heard that Major Carter of Nyngan had been seen to England from 3rd Btn with shell shock. In afternoon went to canteen

& got chocolates & Dry Ginger ale.
Entry.63: btn hopped over this morning. Heard the heavy barrage.
Entry.64: Up 6am cleaned up camp & moved off about 8am. Marched 2 miles to a paddock & after waiting 2 hrs got into motor buses. Left Ypres 2.30pm & just as we were in outskirts of town a shell lobbed quite close. Travelled via Poperinghe, Abeele, Steenvoorde, Cassel, Arques & Wizernes to Drionville where we left the bus then walked to our old billets at Wismes arriving 7.30pm. Very cold frosty night.
Entry.65:
Had splendid comfortable sleep. Got up

8.15am. Bread & jam for breakfast & after having it went to a Froggies house & had boiled eggs & coffee costing 2 francs for the two of us. Out in morning cleaning rifles & bayonet & fitting equipment.
Entry.66: Have been in No10 Stationary hospital, St Omer, since last Tuesday with Myalgia & have been very ill with it. Today am feeling slightly better & more inclined to write. Food is very scanty & not too good. Came in motor ambulance from Wismes. Second day in temp was 101 but is today just above normal. Have a boiled egg at tea time each day & custard for supper.
Entry.67:
Very cold all

day – feeling little better.
Entry.68: Still improving. Food is too scarce though. Cold
Entry.69: Got up for a while after dinner. Very cold.
Entry.70: Wet cold day. Expect to leave any day now.
Entry.71: Aches & pains got worse today so transferred to No59 General Hospital,
Entry.72: Section at Moulle almost 7 kilos from St Omer.
Entry.73: Heard tremendous gunfire all last night & all today. Told by chap from
Entry.74:
British Division that they have been in a secret camp at Dunkirk for 4 months practising landing from monitors. No one was allowed in the camps and they were not allowed out

anywhere. Camp had a special railway built to it for supply purposes etc. Heard tonight Ostend captured. Aches & pains seem worse than ever. Wrote home.
Entry.75: Wrote home. Received 1 letter from Ma, 3 from Muriel, 2 from Aunt Sara, 1 from Aunt Jean, & 1 from Perc Partridge & 1 from Barron. Wrote to Aunts Jean & Sarah.
Entry.76: Wrote to Guild & Perc Partridge. Received letter from Dick Luscombe.
Entry.77: Wrote home also sent several field post cards.
Entry.78: Wrote Uncle Charlie. Put on Light Hospital Duties. Concerts last night & tonight.
Entry.79:
Received 3 letters from

Mother, 1 from Partridge, & 1 each from Uncles Fred & Charlie. Wrote to Mrs Pearce & Mrs Holsom. After tea went to a concert in Moulle given by Jesmond Jesters.
Entry.80: Sent 18 ppcards of Hazebrouck to different friends.
Entry.82: Received letters from Muriel & Uncle Will.
Entry.84: Recd. letter from Ma. Icy cold wind blowing making place bitterly cold. Wrote to Editor, Anzac Bulletin identifying a photo of Lanagan (in a group) taken from a German prisoner on Sept 9th.
Entry.86: Received letters from Ma, Muriel & Uncle Charlie & cards from Ivie, Uncle Harry, Aunt Sara, Aunt Jean, Amanda & a letter from Ivie. Wrote to Ivie & Uncle Charles. Also sent to Uncle Charlie letter authorising my share of Grandma’s letter to be sent to Mother & her receipt to do for same.
Entry.87: Wrote to Amanda & sent card etc home.
Entry.91: Last Monday a Sgt Simmonds Bedford Regt came in & he was in capture of Schwaben Redoubt, Thiepval,
Entry.92:
He told us it was most

luxurious in fitting out. Had electric light, hot & cold baths, tennis court & dozens of racquets etc. When they captured it they caught a Hun Colonel in the bath so sent him down to our lines stark naked & one of the Tommies planted his boot in the Colonel’s stern, making him look very comical. Sent Field Post Card to Muriel, also picture cards to England & Mother & Muriel
Entry.93:
Met chap in hospital who worked on Coronga Peak Station at Byrock. Voted for Conscription Referendum last Wednesday. Few flakes snow fell

today. Wrote home.
Entry.94: Sleet then fairly heavy fall of snow. Cold. Wrote to Uncle Fred & Mr Southwell.
Entry.96: Wrote home. Out gathering Ivy for decorations this morning.
Entry.97:
– fairly cold. Had Xmas dinner in YMCA 
hall
 tent; being waited on by Officer patients & Nurses. Had Roast Beef, Potatoes, Beans, Xmas Pudding (Plum) Stout & Beer Nuts & Fruit – Colonel carved. Whist drive in afternoon but did not go – first prize was Gillett Sfty Razor. Tea laid out in ward consisting of jelly fruit trifle etc all mixed up, biscuits etc.

Games in reception swim after tea. Did not go, stopped at fire all night till 9.30pm. Recd 2 letters from Mother, 1 from Aunt jean, & p/card from Minnie Luscombe. Recd Xmas boxes from British Red Cross & Aust Red Cross.
Entry.98: – 4 or 5 inches snow fell during night so everything is now white. After dinner YMCA gave a concert in Reception room & supplied biscuits cake & tea making very enjoyable afternoon. Had salmon & chicken for tea. Several falls of snow during day.
Entry.99:
Marked Convalescent Camp today. Wrote to Aunt Jean & to home. Concert in afternoon given by

staff of No 1 section 59 Hospital.
Entry.100: Left 12 noon per car for St Omer, there took train & arrived at Boulogne almost 6pm passing through Calais. Then taken in big motor cars to No 7 Convalescent Camp about 3 kilos from Boulogne. Bitterly cold travelling. Feet nearly frozen.
Entry.101: Slept fairly well. Paraded 10am for classification & marked"Three" i.e. a route march only each day. Bitterly cold all day. Could not get my feet warm.
Entry.102:
Paraded sick with the Myalgia & doctor said he could recommend me for "Board". Had 2 or 3 parades out in the cold. Wind & snowy ground. After tea went to a pantomime called

Cinderella – all performers being from Con Camp. Was very good.
Entry.103: New Year Day. Had a route march around Napoleon’s monument, about ½ mile from camp. Bitterly cold gale blowing. Heard naval gunfire last night. Heard today that there was a big row at the Base, Le Havre. Wrote to Dick Lusc, & Uncle Fred.
Entry.104: Snowing today & very cold. Wrote home.
Entry.105: Wrote Uncle Charlie. Very cold & snowing again, heavily.
Entry.106:
Recd letter from Uncle Fred. Heard Fred Charlton been knocked. Told by a chap in 32nd btn that they had a train smash almost a month ago – 68 injured & couple died since. Caused by couplings of carriages breaking when

within about 200 yds of destination when coming down from line. Carriages telescoped & one this chap was in was smashed to pieces injuring him, also all his platoon except 7 or 8. Temperature much milder & all snow thawed away making place very sloppy. Met Bob Clarke who came down from No 59 2 days ago. Had supper with him.
Entry.107: Saw French airship. Milder temperature. Had couple route marches. Had supper with Bob Clarke.
Entry.108: Read letter from Mr Randall. Raining all morning. After dinner went down to Boulogne for 4 or 5 hours & had tea down there – steak, chips & coffee costing 2fr 2½.
Entry.110: Snowed again last night. Very cold again. Marked to see a Specialist. Bob Clarke marked for Ecault Con Camp. Wrote home.
Entry.111: Very strong gale blowing but not so cold. Rained heavily during night. In morning taken by motor to No 83 (Dublin) Hospital on the Wimureux Road right on the coast. There saw a specialist & he said he would sent a report on my case.
Entry.112: Very heavy gale blowing all night. Recd letter from Uncle Fred. The colonel inspected me this morning on recommendation of specialist – only asked 3 or 4 questions. Calm afternoon. Paid 20 francs. Yesterday recd our weekly Aust. Red Cross issue
Entry.114: Very mild temperature. Wrote to Uncle Fred. Went up to top of Napoleon’s tower but could not see across to England on account of the haze.
Entry.115: Recd letters from Guild & Partridge. Still mild.
Entry.116: Read letter from Uncle Will & answered same. Sent parcel to Australia last Thursday.
Entry.117: Recd letter from home & answered same.
Entry.118:
Wrote to Bob Clarke. Marked No Four at the inspection. Sold revolver for 15 francs to the barman

in beer tent. Had yarn to a chap today who is in the Aust. 9.2" siege battery. He was at the Cambrai push & nearly got cut off when the Germans broke through. Told me a 11" shell fell just under his loading platform but fortunately did not burst.
Entry.119:
After tea went to an estaminet & had 2 eggs chips beetroot bread & butter costing 2½ francs each. Had coffee & rum to wash it down. Saw 2 airships along the coast. 

26/1/18 Recd parcel from Australia containing 4 pcs chocolate, tin unsweetened milk & tin milk & coffee. Little colder not feeling too good. Heard 4th &
Entry.120:
divisions hopping over at Ypres tomorrow night. Fritz

aeroplanes over Boulogne last night & there was a great barrage of anti-aircraft gunfire.
Entry.122: Marked Medical Board by Colonel today so going to base Details camp tomorrow. Sent change of address to Base Post Office. Still fine. Fritz aeroplane over about 12 noon.
Entry.123: Wrote to Mr Southwell. Came to Base Details Camp 1.30pm & put into Bell Tents. Given a job in the Dining Hall but squared with the Sgt to get off of it. Had army biscuits & jam & butter for tea. After tea went to an estimanet with Roelig & had Steak Chips & Beetroot costing 2.40 each. Steak was beautiful & tender.
Entry.124:
After tea went to Boulogne with Roelig. Had eggs & sausages

at the Salvation Army costing 1.80 each. Saw Richter who was in No 10 Hospital with me
Entry.125: Had overcoat stolen after dinner today. Got an old one at 7 Con Camp & then got British Warmer for 15 francs & the old coat.
Entry.126: After tea went with Roelig & chap from
Entry.127: btn to estaminet & had steak chips & beetroot & coffee costing 2fr 2½ each. Then walked half way to Boulogne to fill in the evening.
Entry.128:
Warned for base today. Leaving about 4.30pm. Been buying salmon sandwiches to eat on the way. Bought 1 doz Boulogne post cards for 14½. Left camp 4.30pm & caught train at Boulogne – Tintelleries at 6.30pm

Travelled via Etaples, Abbeville, Bacouel, Serqueux, Sommery, Monterolier – Buchy, Morgny, Rouen, Maromme, Motteville to Havre arriving about 10pm. Marched to the Tommy Camp & given cup of tea & slice bread & dripping & after waiting over an hour marched to our base about 1am. Is very pretty around Rouen very hilly & several tunnels high embankments & viaducts on the railway. It has a great number of factories & seems a very big town altho’ could not see too well on account of mist.
Entry.129: Slept in till 9.30am. Could not eat any breakfast as not feeling well. Was taken very sick in train after leaving Rouen having bit of dry retching. Wrote home.
Entry.130: Sent into hospital again today. The Dr here is the one I saw when first reported sick at Ypres & then again at the Field Ambulance when first went into hospital
Entry.131: Food excellent at this hospital. Best have had in France. An Aust. lady in this afternoon issuing toilet necessaries to all men.
Entry.132: Sent picture post cards of Boulogne to Australia.
Entry.133: Marked out of hospital & recommended for Medical Board. After tea went into hospital & played 3 or 4 games of chess.
Entry.134: Went before Board and marked"Temporary Base 3 weeks". Recd letter from Uncle Fred.
Entry.135:
Wrote to Uncle Fred. Met Jack Murray who was in

Com. Bank at Bourke. He is a Cpl in the 34th Btn. Told me he came over on"Anchises" when I came. Also met a chap named Lester who came in 9/53rd with us. Gave me all the news of the old chaps. A big draft of new reinforcements also arrived. They left Sydney in August & travelled via Panama Canal & Nova Scotia & landed at Glasgow in October. Recd 20 francs pay this afternoon. Wrote home.
Entry.136: Very cold & frosty last 3 days. Met a Jock today returned from the Italian Front. Met Harry Holt yesterday & Snowy Peat 4 days ago.
Entry.138: divs gassed by Germans with a new gas a few days ago. Still cold. Received letter from Uncle Charlie.
Entry.139: Went to pictures with Murray & then to Canteen & had supper of Tinned rabbit. Temperature much milder.
Entry.140: Issued with new boots & tunic. Wrote home.
Entry.141: Met palmer of 6th Btn. He was wounded on Oct 31st at Ypres & arrived yesterday from England on his way back to the line. Told me Burrell & Snowy James both going to Australia.
Entry.142: Palmer went up to line this morning, also Murray.
Entry.143: Recd letters from Uncle Fred & Mr Southwell. Latter says he will probably be made a chaplain.
Entry.144:
Met 2 Railway unit chaps who left Melbourne on Nov 7th.

They came via Colombo, Suez – thence rail to Alexandria – Boat to Taranto, Italy – 7 days ride in train to Cherbourg – thence across to S Hampton. Said they did not get on too well with the Italians. Not so cold.
Entry.146: Went to concert by Lena Ashwell party after tea.
Entry.147: Snowing heavily. Had game of chess with Crackenthorpe who is ex-champion of Australia.
Entry.149: Met Billy Thorpe of Ft Stn at Salvation Hut when having cocoa. Gave me all the Bourke news. Told me Bill Forsythe had transferred to Artillery & was now in France. Bill was with Forsythe in England. Rained nearly all day.
Entry.150:
Before Medical Board again

& marked B1 (1 week). Met Budge Woods of Bourke who arrived from England today. Told me Barrett was a Corporal & heard Forsythe killed. Went to concert last night in Salvation Army Hut. Wrote to Dick Luscombe, Uncle Charlie, Base Post Office & home & sent cossie picture to Maggie Fitz.
Entry.152: After tea went to concert given by R.G.A. Concert party. Warned to go away at any time.
Entry.153:
Got pack ready to leave the camp & all lined up on parade ground – the marched to Medical Hut & examined by doctors. I was pulled out of the draft with three

or four other chaps. Nice & fine.
Entry.154:
Nice fine sunshine. Met chap at Artillery camp other day who came on transport via Panama Canal – taking 8 hours to go through it; from 6am to 2 pm. They were at Halifax, Nova Scotia 10 days after big explosion. After dinner over 200 of us went out with Chaplain Gault for a couple hours to a beech forest – planted about 50 years ago. He gave out lollies & cigarettes etc & gave prizes for an essay and competition on"The most beautiful sight I have seen". Some were comic but the winning essays were very good. I did not compete as I have no eye for beauty. After tea

went to Artillery Camp & heard Chaplain Gault preach.
Entry.155:
On Board again & marked"B1T" i.e. to do a little physical training 
Received parcels from Mrs Nancarrow & Easie
. Recd parcels from Mrs N & Easie. Wrote to them both thanking them for same. After tea went to a lecture (lantern) on the Royal Navy by Commander Eldred RN
Entry.156: After tea went to concert in Salvation Hall by"Son’s of Guns" party – nearly all of whom are professionals. Was very good.
Entry.157: Started on the physical training, makes my back pain good deal. After tea went to concert in YMCA by some American ladies, not too bad then went to R.G.A. band for about an hour.
Entry.159: Dull & cloudy. Playing chess nearly all day.
Entry.161:
time. Was marked BII T . Rec’d letter from Aunt Jean. Met Roach of the R.F.A today. He came from Con Camp on Tuesday last. Had yarn with Abell & friend he had often been to Bourke fixing up a printing machine for Phil Chapman. He stopped at Fitz’s hotel & knew them all; also Sineiros, Goldman etc. Told me he fixed up Sineiro’s car once. Answered Aunt Jeans letter. Abell is also in 35th btn. 

Rained heavily in afternoon.
Entry.162: Fine sunshine. Saw in"Weekly Times" of Melbourne a photo of Jacob Jacobsen of Macarthur. He was killed in action.
Entry.163: Went to cricket match in afternoon between 2nd &
Entry.165: A chap tried to cut his throat when we were away at breakfast & died later in day. All leave for Tommies stopped yesterday on account of Fritz offensive.
Entry.166: Recd parcel from Australia containing Vest, u/pants, Writing Pad & Envelopes, Tooth Paste & Brush. Turned very cold in afternoon.
Entry.167:
Recd parcel from Kitten Fitz containing Sox, Hdcf, Chewing Gum & Toffee. On Medical Board again & marked BIII i.e. Permanently unfit. Wrote to Nip Morris & Kitten Fitz &

Mr Southwell. Very cold all day & showery rain.
Entry.168: Paid today. Wrote home. Fairly cold & fine. Met a chap named Boldra of 4th btn who was in camp with me at Dubbo.
Entry.169: Warned at 9am to go on PB draft at 5pm. Full marching order less rifle, bayonet, & ammunition. Started raining after dinner. Left Havre Camp at 5.40pm, left camp adjutants 6.30pm & caught a tram through Havre arriving Gare maritime about 7.30pm. Am placed in charge of 2 other chaps & going to No1 C.C.S. Estaires. Raining heavily again.
Entry.170:
Got into trucks of a leave train plying between Arras & Havre at about 11pm. last night. Train left 1.45am.

& arrived at Rouen about 7am but did not get off until about 8.30am. Then went to a Rest Camp about 600 yds from station. At 10am went back to the station to the R.T.O & received instructions to get in another train at 2 p.m. today. At Rouen station saw trainloads of wounded from the big stunt some coming down in trucks. Also saw some refugees from Amiens. Was talking to a wounded Tommy from 66th division & he had been in a stunt from first day & in it 7 days – retreating from front line to beyond Peronne. His battalion went in about 900 strong & came out about 40. Said 66th divsn is now

only 200 or 300 strong all told. When at the Rouen Rest Camp met Woodger who was with me at La Peronse. Set 18 picture ppcards of Rouen to Australia. Entrained again at Rouen 2p.m. Travelled via Sommery, Serqueux, Gaillefontaine, Abancourt, & Etaples.
Entry.171:
Arrived at Etaples during night & stopped till 1pm. While there saw some Australians on a hospital train & they had been in the big stunt. Told me we had retaken Albert & that Australians Canadians & New Zealanders were holding the Fritzs about Albert & Doullens. Said that 40th Aust Btn has been wiped out. Continued travelling via Boulogne, Calais, St Omer, Ebblinghem & Hazebrouck, arriving at latter about 8pm to a rest billet for the night. The rest billet was a big place that had been

recently struck by a Fritz shell & was almost ready to topple over.
Entry.172: Up 6.45am & caught train at 9.21am travelling via Steenbeeck, Berguette, St Venant, Calonne, Merville to La Gorgue just near Estaire, arriving at 1.30am. Then marched to a reinforcement billet in Estaire & supplied with stew. Moved off again at 3.10pm for the C.C.S. near Outtersteene & got a lift almost all the way on 3 different motor lorries, passing through villages Neuf-Berquin & Vieux-Berquin. Arrived at CCS about 5pm & had tea & then saw the O.C. (Lt Col Marks) who seems very genial & were well received by him. Wrote to Base PO giving change of address.
Entry.173:
Up 6.15am & breakfast 6.45am & started

work 7.30am helping in moving the C.C.S. to another place near Hazebrouck. Had tea & biscuits at smoko & dinner at 11.45am tea 4.45pm then did 1½ hours work, & at 8pm had supper of nice sweet cocoa & bread & jam. After supper went out for a stroll along the road. Suppose this place about 15 kilos from front line.
Entry.174: Fairly heavy gunfire during the night till about 7am. Last 2 days nice & fine with cold nights. Working all day again. After tea went along road about 2 kilos. Moved to another hut.
Entry.175:
Rained heavily during night. After tea went for walk with Degrandy to within about 1 kilo of Baillieul. At 7pm went to a concert given by Aussies

billeted close to the C.C.S. 

Put on job hunting away French schmiddies on account of them stealing.
Entry.176: Dull & overcast. After tea walked to Meteren., about 2 kilos. Bought ppcards of the place. On the way in had haircut & shave at a French barbers. Charged 1 franc & 3. A woman helps him with the shaving.
Entry.177: Drizzling rain all day. Put on a job cleaning up for Capt. Barton. After tea went into Outtersteene, almost 1¾ kilos.
Entry.178: Nice fine morning but at 5pm it started raining again. After tea went into Meteren with Degrandy. Had nice hot bath after tea.
Entry.179: Fine day. After dinner washed my underclothing also pair of slacks I salvaged. After tea walked to Le Steetze. Great aerial & artillery activity.
Entry.180:
Cloudy morning & wet afternoon also

very cold. Guns fairly active all day.
Entry.181:
Foggy last night & this morning. Very heavy artillery barrage started about 4.30am. Several shells fell fairly close to C.C.S, probably Baillieul. Artillery fire very heavy all day & in afternoon considerable machine gun fire. After tea we were told to stand by & not leave the camp. No 2 British C.C.S evacuated during today. Saw some despatch riders after tea & they gave us the news. Fritz attacked the Portuguese & they cleared out leaving our flanks open. Heard Fritz took Sailly & reached La Gorgue, also that Estaires has been smashed up. A Tommy told us legs & arms were lying about everywhere & numbers of people buried in the ruins. About 4pm

all roads about here became extremely busy, there being hundreds of motor transport & Red Cross cars also refugees. At 9pm hauled out of bed & had to load up my wagons with stretchers. Then given 10 minutes to pack up our belongings & place them in the cars. Lined up about 10.30pm & Colonel told off certain of us for the cars & remainder had to march to the new C.C.S. I arrived 1.30am.
Entry.182: Slept well & rose about 8.30am. Given a job about 10am carrying material for huts. After dinner got job bearing wounded & at it till bedtime.
Entry.183: Wet in morning. Great number of wounded passing through. Heavy machine gun & artillery fire.
Entry.184: Started moving hospital further back again to Arques I heard. All hands working till about 2am. Nice fine day & great aerial activity. Fritz planes over during the night.
Entry.185: Busy clearing up till 10.30am then all hands allowed to rat the Q.M. stores. 200 or 300 Jocks also came over & assisted. Was very amusing to see them. Moved off about 12.15pm & marched via Hondeghem, Staple, Ebblinghem, Arques to Blendecques arriving about 7.45pm. No2 A.C.C.S is here alongside ours & No 17 British C.C.S about 250 yds away.
Entry.186:
Very cold & windy. Put on job cleaning up billets. Went to an estimanet at 11am & had coffee & bread & butter. Wrote home. After tea went into Blendecques

with De Grandi. Had cup of coffee each & bought butter & bread.
Entry.187: Very cold, windy & dull. After tea went to Blendecques with De Grandi & had omelette & chips costing 2½ fr. each
Entry.188: Not so cold. After tea had 2 fried eggs & coffee costing 1½ fr. Very heavy artillery fire about 8pm
Entry.189: Recd parcel from Aunt Sarah containing Sweets, Sox & Soap & wrote letter acknowledging same. Had a bath at Froggies place & got Vernon to dress my heel. After tea had Egg & chips costing 2 fr each. Hay & Foch are sleeping at Blendeque tonight. Very heavy Anglo-French barrage all day.
Entry.190:
Very cold & drizzling rain. Started in Sisters Mess after

dinner. Finished there 9pm.
Entry.191: Recd parcel from Muriel posted Jany 30th. Very cold.
Entry.192: Heavy white frost & very cold again.
Entry.193: Frosty morning but fine sunshine all day. Fritz aeroplanes over. Sick of job already.
Entry.194: Not so cold. Tried to change to Officers mess. No success so far.
Entry.196: Commenced receiving wounded today. They include Fritzs & French.
Entry.197: Temperature mild & misty. Raining during night. Sent service card to Uncle Fred & wrote home.
Entry.198: After Back being painful for 5 or 6 days got real bad today so had to go sick & sent into hospital again.
Entry.199: Just told today the White Chateau on hill is where Lord Roberts died. Yesterday had several strange doctors in to see my heart. They included a staff officer.
Entry.200: Got up after lunch after being 4 days in bed. Feel very weak & faint. Wrote home & send ppcards of Meteren to Australia.
Entry.201: Recd parcel of Griffiths Bros from Aust. containing cake, raisins, lollies & peaches. Up all day today.
Entry.202: Went into Wizernes on south side of railway & back on the north side.
Entry.203: After dinner walked to Bilques & had a look at its church. Before dinner several of the doctors looked at heart with X Rays.
Entry.204:
After dinner went to"Cinder 

Camp" & had hot bath.
Entry.205: Had 4 X Ray photos taken funny machine. Drs say backbone is alright. Discharged from hospital. After lunch walked to Helfaut 3½ kilos distance. There saw a memorial stone in honour of a benefactor of the town who had lived about 1628-1692.
Entry.206: Started in Officers Mess again. After tea walked to Aviation Camp near St Omer & saw several aeroplanes starting their flight. Very warm &^ fine. Fritz planes over last 4 or 5 nights.
Entry.207:
Blendecques & surroundings very heavily bombed by Fritz planes last night. He caught an ammunition dump near Arques & cause big blaze.

Has been over every night during the last week.
Entry.208: Several trainloads of American troops passing through going towards Lumbres.
Entry.210: After lunch walked over the hill to Bilques.
Entry.212:
Recd letter from Uncle Fred. Nice fine warm day & foggy early this morning. Very heavy artillery fire during night. During morning saw squadron of 9 aeroplanes going towards Fritz lines & 4pm saw another squadron of 12 – apparently heavily laden with bombs. Also noticed a line of trenches has

been surveyed across hill towards Bilques.
Entry.214: Nice fine day & atmosphere exceedingly clear. Everything seems to be magnified. Fairly cold after tea.
Entry.215: After dinner (2pm) went to St Omer & looked around the place. Went & saw Notre Dame & the old ruins. Is a very pretty walk in & back. Arrived back again 7.30pm.
Entry.217:
After tea went to aerodrome & inspected several aeroplanes at close quarters. One was a Nieuport Scout with a Le Rhone engine of 110 horse power. It had a stationary shaft &

the engine revolved. In afternoon went on top of hill close by & saw that 2nd &
Entry.218: line trenches are being made. Nice fine day, cool early in morning.
Entry.219: Received acknowledgement of my letter from Australian Base Post Office.
Entry.220: After tea went to aerodrome & saw observation & fighting planes. One observation plane (2 seater) started its flight when I was there. In the shed saw a Bristol 2 seater fighting plane with 1 machine gun & 2 Lewis guns. It had 264 horse power Rolls-Royce engine & capable of speed about 120 miles per hr. Several trainloads of Americans have passed through last 3 days.
Entry.221: Cold change. More trainloads of Americans came through
Entry.222:
Americans playing Base ball

here this morning. They are crew of an American Hospital train. Had hot shower at Bellevue House.
Entry.223: Received letters from Auntie Effie dated 8/4/18, Uncle Jim dated 14/4/18 & Muriel dated 21/4/18.
Entry.224: During afternoon went to aerodrome with Macdonald, the NZ, & saw several planes. Saw 4 20lb Cooper bombs being shipped to an SE plane. Just missed chance of a trip in a plane.
Entry.226: Recd parcel from Muriel posted on
Entry.227: Contains 1 pr Sox & Khaki Hdfs. A Btn of Tommies just arrived from Palestine marched past here today.
Entry.228:
Recd letters from Muriel & Minnie Luscombe.

Wrote to Auntie Effie & Minnie Luscombe.
Entry.229: Recd 2 parcels – one containing 1 pr Brown Sox, & 1 ctn Griffiths Chocolate, & other Cake, Biscuits, Sardines, Strawberry Conserve, Pineapple, Tomato Soup, Chocolate & Milk & Butterscotch.
Entry.230: Receiving wounded today who were in a stunt near Meteren during which our people advanced. Wrote to Muriel. Raining today. Wrote to Dick Luscombe.
Entry.231: Recd parcel from Mother contng Caps (From Minnie Lusc) Insecticide Butterscotch, Soap, Hdfs, Boot Laces, Writing Pad & Tooth Brush. It was posted
Entry.233:
Recd 2 parcels 1 contg big tin of Griffiths Chocolate & the other Lollies, Ginger, Preserved Peaches

Chocolate, Raisins, Fruit Cake & Paste; sent by Griffiths Bros.
Entry.235: Recd letter from Dick Luscombe. Three trainloads of Yanks passed through today going towards Lumbres. Fritz planes over last two nights.
Entry.237: About 11pm last night American troops marched past our camp towards line. Were going by pretty well all night & this morning.
Entry.238: Feeling very tired & off colour altogether during afternoon.
Entry.239: Had bad night. Reported such at 9am & sent into hospital with Spanish Influenza. Temp 100 in morning and 103.8 at 6pm.
Entry.240: Recd letters from Mother, Amanda & Mrs Brown. Still feeling very off & cannot eat.
Entry.241: Feeling much better. Had first food for 60 hours. Very hot.
Entry.242: Much cooler. Wrote home & to Uncle Fred
Entry.244: Up this afternoon for first time. Head still sore & a buzzing in the ears. last Friday met a Froggy up on top of hill at back of camp & he told me the three mounds are for French soldiers who died about 1839. Wrote to Amanda.
Entry.245:
Met a Jock today who has just returned from Palestine. He told me our troops were severely dealt with & lost 9 guns when they crossed 

the River Jordan: Also told me Jericho is 1600 ft 
below
 sea level & 20 miles from Jerusalem which is 3000 ft 
above
 sea level .
Entry.246: Had nice hot shower at Cinder Camp, Blendecques.
Entry.247: Received bid Australian mail comprising letters dated from Oct 21st to
Entry.248:
They included letters from Mother, Muriel, Aunts Jean & Sarah, Ivie, Mr Hatten, Perc Partridge & Mr Randell, also couple old letters from Uncle Fred & Dick Lusc. Wrote to Mr Randell & Perc Partridge. Inspected by General Birdwood this afternoon. He spoke to several of us including myself. The Colonel had told him of my heart & he appeared

to be rather interested.
Entry.249: rec’d letter from Mother dated 23/2/18 & card from Guild. in hospital in England dated 3/5/18. Wrote to Aunt Sara, Ivie & Mr Hatten. Very heavy thunder storm & rain last night – Very close today. At 11am a big Handley-Page two engined plane passed overhead. Heard Palmer of 6th Btn shot just under heart with machine gun bullet,
Entry.250: Wrote home. After tea went past the aerodrome to Longuenesse. Very hot & muggy.
Entry.251: In afternoon walked to Bilques & Heuringhem – made me very tired.
Entry.252:
Wrote to Dick Luscombe. Had interesting talk with two Yankee sergeants after tea. They are attached to this unit for

a few days to gain experience. Could see 7 observation balloons over line.
Entry.253: Warned for evacuation at lunch time. Left for hospital train 7pm boarding it at Blendecque Rly Stn.
Entry.254: Train started at 9pm last night & travelled via Arques, St Omer, Calais, Boulogne & Neufchatel to Dannes-Camiers. After about an hours wait we got off the train & were taken in motors to 42nd Stationary Hospital. It is right alongside the railway & does not seem a bad place. Had been travelling & had no sleep so after a hot shower went to bed & slept soundly.
Entry.255: Wrote to Mac at the C.C.S. Dr told me was being recommended for another board.
Entry.256: Raining all day. After tea went to pictures at YMCA. Hospital is only about 1 mile from beach.
Entry.257: After tea went to top of big hill at back of camp. Had a grand view of the English Channel & surrounding country. Can see Le Toquet quite distinctly.
Entry.258: After tea went over hill for a walk.
Entry.259: Raining heavily during morning. Marked for Con Camp & Board.
Entry.260:
Drew kit from pack store at 12pm & had to walk to Etaples to the medical Board Base Depot – arrived there about 4pm. It is an awful camp, the worst have ever struck. It consists of bell tents lowered about 12 ft into the ground & just the earth floor to lie on. Have only been

issued with one blanket.
Entry.261: Slept pretty well. Inspected by Dr at 8am – having Board tomorrow. After tea went into Etaples with Pynn of
Entry.262: Batln & a Tommy. Had eggs & chips costing 2 francs each – absolute robbery. Numbers of houses blown down by Fritz bombs. Saw a house where Napoleon stopped in 1904 – a tablet is on the house to commemorate the occasion. Fairly warm all day.
Entry.263: Marked B3 on the Board. Met chap named Cohen who travelled for WH Paling & Co on the West line. He used to stop at Bradstreets Hotel, Bourke. He belongs to 36 Battalion & was on Board with me today.
Entry.264:
Up at 4.30am & after a 

roll call marched about ½ mile to employment base depot No3 right on shore of Estuary. Had a nice hot shower there & good drink ginger beer at canteen. Wrote to Postal Clerk of CCS. asking him to hold my letters pro tem. Warned to leave for Havre at 5pm. Left camp at 5pm for train, only about ¼ hour walk. Train left at 6.10pm.
Entry.265:
Travelled all night via St Josse, Rang-du-Fliers Verton, went around Abbeville, Quesnoy, Rouen, Malauney, Motteville, Yvetot, Gainville, & arrived at Harfleur about 11am, & arrived at general Base Depot about 1.30pm feeling very tired. Noticed railway is being quadrupled between Etaples

& Abbeville, & around Abbeville new lines branch forth in all directions. Very hot today. Slept in afternoon.
Entry.266: Marked for another Board today & was also inoculated. Wrote home. Was inoculated today making me feel very much off colour.
Entry.267: Marked"A" (ie active) on medical board. Will be going back to CCS in a few days. Met the 17th btn corporal with whom I played a good deal of chess last March.
Entry.268: Has been raining ever since I came to Havre but looks finer today. Went to a band concert after tea with Spencer.
Entry.269: At the Gas school all morning. Raining heavily all afternoon.
Entry.270:
After lunch went into Havre

with Cohen – getting train at Rouelles at 2pm & arriving about 2.15pm. Had good look all around the town & enjoyed ourselves immensely. Had eggs, tomatoes, bread butter & tea at 4pm at Crystal Palace YMCA & at 6.30pm had dinner at the Restaurant du Plat de l’Agent – having four courses for 3½ francs. Was an excellent dinner. Caught 8.30pm train & arrived back at the camp about 9pm.
Entry.271: Warned for draft coming back to CCS. Leaving 6.15pm tonight. Left camp at 6.30pm & marched to Gare Maritime (Havre) arriving about 8.30pm.
Entry.272:
Train left 2am & arrived at Rouen 7am & then we went to the Rest Camp alongside the river & were supplied with breakfast by the canteen.

Went into city for 2 hours & had a good feed at a restaurant 4 francs each for dinner & beer. Saw a fine cathedral I think & several ancient buildings. Went to station again at 2pm & train left at 3.30pm & travelled same old route.
Entry.273:
Had good sleep on floor of train & arrived at Calais 6am. There saw R.T.O & he told me C.C.S. has left Blendecques & gone down to the Somme, so am going down there this afternoon. Left Calais 2pm & arrived Etaples 5pm & R.T.O there told us to go on to Abbeville. I then happened to meet 3 chaps who had only left C.C.S. yesterday & they told me it was still at Blendecques, so saw RTO again & told him.

He then gave me a ticket for the No 9 Rest Camp & to report to him 7a.m. tomorrow morning. Had good walk through Calais when there & bought picture ppcards of the place.
Entry.274:
Up 6am went to sidings 7am & train left 9am. When passing through Marquise saw an airship starting its flight. Arrived St Omer about 3pm & road in a motor lorry to Blendecques arriving about 4p.m. Recd 2 letters from Mother, 2 from Muriel, & 1 each from Mr Nancarrow, Alma & Dick Lusc

Saw Colonel on arrival at CCS & he is going to write to base about me.
Entry.275:
Sent to Officers Mess again. Wrote to Mr Nancarrow & Cohen, Uncle Fred & home. After tea walked as far as Longuenesse. The trench system

in this district is now practically completed.
Entry.276: Finished in Officers Mess this morning & started in Mens Mess with Littlejohn. After tea walked to Gondardennes. Answered Alma’s letter.
Entry.278: Recd letter from W Macdonald. Saw dozens of motor lorries & motor buses packed with troops going towards the line on the Abbeville road near St Omer.
Entry.279:
Genl. Birdwood here again today also last Tuesday. Genl. Smuts here last Sunday & Duchess of Sutherland a few days ago. Heard today the Colonel is doing his best to have me sent back to Australia.

18/8/1/ Recd letters from Uncle Jim, Mrs Brown, Muriel & Amanda & a 

letter card from Partridge. Saw a mans leg being amputated this afternoon.
Entry.280: Wrote to Mrs Brown, Uncle Jim & Amanda.
Entry.281: Wrote to Partridge & Dick Lusc. very hot all day. Paid today.
Entry.282: Very hot again. Feeling off colour nearly all day.
Entry.283: After tea went to aerodrome & saw several planes land & start. Saw a Yankee pilot with a British machine also a Capt Shields who has downed 30 German planes. Cooler today.
Entry.284: Rather cold last night. Wrote to Muriel. Went for walk after tea with Watty Last.
Entry.286:
A team of Sth Africans here playing cricket this afternoon.

They included a couple of"Springboks"
Entry.287: Recd p/card from Cohen at home.
Entry.288: Recd letter from Mother written on
Entry.290: Recd letter from Dick Luscombe. Just told today we are to go up near Ebblinghem. Marching up I think. Wrote home.
Entry.291:
recd letters from Mother dated 5/11/17, 25/11/17, 7/12/17, 23/12/17, & a Xmas Card for 1917 from Mrs Doyle. Taking down the tents today. During afternoon went on top of hill & as atmosphere was very clear had a magnificent view. Could see Cassel, Mont des Cats, Mont Rouge & Kemmel in the distance; & to the Sth East could see a long ridge right out past the three slag heaps. After tea went to aerodrome & saw an aeroplane that had smashed up when landing. Great numbers

of troops passing through here on the railway.
Entry.292: Left Blendecques at 2pm per motor lorry & arrived at old camp at Hondeghem about 3.30pm travelling via Arques & Renescure. Passed miles of new trenches & ammunition dumps along the road.
Entry.293: Started receiving this morning. Several of them were wounded just near Armentieres. Put on a job guarding a Tommy"mental" case. Heard shifting again up near Bailleul in a few days.
Entry.294: Colonel & several officers went up to old site of CCS near Outtersteene. Place is all shell holes & dead horses everywhere making everything stink. After tea went into Hondeghem with Littlejohn & Bill Dennerstein.
Entry.295:
Received a great number of wounded today. Some were getting into a leave

train at Bailleul when Fritz got it. After tea went for a walk towards Caestre. Saw battery of 8 inch howitzers.
Entry.296: After tea went for walk to outskirts of Hazebrouck with Littlejohn. Raining.
Entry.297: After tea walked to 2 French farms & had coffee & a yarn with Froggies. Saw a wounded Tommy & he said Armentieres is now No Mans land.
Entry.298: Had hot shower near Hazebrouck. Rumours going about that we are moving again. Plenty of rain. Heard firing near St Venant.
Entry.300:
Up 6am & after helping to clear the camp walked to Hondeghem Stn to train leaving there 11am. Travelled via Morbecque, Steenbecque, Thiennes, Bequette to St Venant & are in an old asylum there. Littlejohn & I in charge of mens mess

again. All hands are in a big dormitory – quite a pleasant change after always under canvas. Last night slept with men working at the sisters mess.
Entry.301: Nice fine day. After tea went for walk along Bethune Road. Heavy gunfire last night.
Entry.302: Recd 2 letters from Muriel, being first I have received addressed to the C.C.S. Started work in Orderly Room after dinner, being taken from the mens mess. After tea went for walk along railway towards Calonne with Sinclair – passed over the British front line trenches & got with 200 yds of German old line.
Entry.304:
After tea walked to Guarbecque, about 5 kilos. It has a

very fine church. Turned colder.
Entry.306: Recd parcel from Muriel posted May 31st contg sweets,, chocolates, Sugar, Laces & scrap from Farmers. After tea walked to Robecq. Place is all in ruins, not a place unscathed. Civilians are going back to it though. Fritz shelling this vicinity during night.
Entry.307: Rained during day. Feeling aches & pains all over me.
Entry.308: Nice fine day. After tea walked to Busnes, about 4 kilos, crossing Aire-La Bassee Canal at Pont d’Epinette. Busnes is a Corps headquarters. Is very pretty right along the canal.
Entry.309:
Removed Orderly Room down to the gateway opposite No2 A.C.C.S Fritz aeroplanes over during night & had fights with ours in this vicinity – two of ours came down.

Went down to St Venant after tea with Littlejohn.
Entry.311:
Recd letter & statement of a/c from Mr Randall. Birdwood here today inspecting – told us Americans had taken 20 000 prisoners & Bulgaria asking for armistice.

29/9/18 Very cold & inclined to rain. Recd letters from Mother dated 25/6/18 & 30/6/18, from Muriel dated May 27th, June 16th & 25th, Aunt Sarah dated
Entry.313: Was down at La Bassee canal during morning helping evacuate wounded. Leave pass for Blighty arrived today.
Entry.314:
Left hospital 12.30pm, walked to Berguette Stn, about 6 or 7 kilos , arriving 2pm. left Berguette 3.20pm & travelled via Isbergues, Aire, Blaringhem, Arques St Omer, Watten to Calais arriving

about 5.30pm. Then marched about 3 miles to a rest camp near the coast. It is just outside a big mound, surrounded by anti-aircraft guns which appears to encircle Calais. Recd letter from Cohen just before leaving St Venant. Served with tea after arrival at Rest Camp. Very cold & strong gale today.
Entry.315: Up 6.30am. Nice fine sunshine day but cold wind blowing. Moved to another camp at 10am. After tea went into Calais & had bath & shave.
Entry.316:
Reveille 5.30am & marched to boat 7.30am at Calais near maritime Stn. Sailed 9.15am & arrived Dover 10.45am. Train left 10am (English time) & travelled via Canterbury, Faversham, Gillingham, Chatham

Rochester & Heine Hill to Victoria Station London arriving about 12.30pm. Were escorted across Channel by 3 destroyers & an airship. Saw Dover castle in distance. Went to Horseferry Rd & got fixed up with clothing & money etc. Left H.Q, about 2.30pm getting bus in Victoria St for Tottenham Court Rd, & from latter went to YMCA & was recommended to lodgings in 50 Bloomsbury St where I went & got room to myself, bed & breakfast costing 4/-. Then went to Kings Cross & had pass altered to Aberdeen by the RTO & found out about the train. Went by tube then to the bank (of England) & then walked to Basinghall

St & saw Mr Dick Holsom. He told me Claire Holsom only went back from leave on Monday & that Billy Holsom was passed. He would have taken me out to his place only he has just had an addition to the family. After leaving PB & Cos went back to Tottenham Ct Rd. by Bus, had tea at a restaurant & went per tube via the bank to Clapham Common to see Uncle Charlie. He was out when I arrived at his place so after waiting about ½ hr I left again, after leaving some souvenirs for him to mind. I arrived back about ½ past 9 feeling very tired. On way from Dover by train had a fine view 

of Canterbury Cathedral. Wired Cohen to meet me tomorrow.
Entry.317:
Up 8am after a splendid sleep. Went to Trafalgar Sq. to meet Cohen but he did not turn up so took bus to kings Cross & enquired about trains going north. Decided to leave for Hull by 1.30pm train & go to Filey tomorrow. Went back to lodgings & got my gear & boarded train at ¼ to 1, getting very nice 3rd class corner seat. Train left at 1.30pm and travelled via Hitchin, Huntingdon, Peterboro’, Grantham, Newark, Retford & Doncaster to Selby where I changed to Hull train, left there at 6.5pm & arrived at Hull almost 7pm. Went

to the Imperial Hotel & booked bed & breakfast for 7/-. Then walked down the street along a tram line past a big monument & over the canal bridge (it appeared to be that in the dark), went into a restaurant & had Fish & Chips & Lemonade, then came back to bed. On way up from London, train stopped at Peterboro, Doncaster & Selby only. Train passed little village called Little Bytham near where Grandma Cowling came from. It was too dark to see anything of Hull. The reason is Zeppelin air raids.
Entry.318:
Up 7.30am & after breakfast went down into Hull & had look

around. Bought ppcards & 2 books of views of Hull & posted letters top Mother & Amanda Cowling. Saw the monumental columns again & found it was to Wilberforce in connection with the abolition of slavery. Caught a train at 11am & travelled via Beverly, Driffield, Bridlington, Flamborough to Filey & walked out to Muston arriving about 2pm. Uncle Will is away (they have sent for him) but Auntie & Ida were home. Hull is a very nice clean city & Bridlington seems a fine town. Saw Flamborough Head. Went to bed 9pm.
Entry.319:
Slept like a top in a lovely bed. After breakfast walked into Filey & had a look around. Bought views

of place & had a shave. Also bought some sweets for Ida & Honey for Auntie. Both seemed very pleased. Name of Auntie’s brother at London Harley Trust is Mr Estill. Uncl Will came back during morning. After tea Uncle, Ida & self walked to Hunmanby & then Ida went further on with her . Rained slightly today but not nearly so cold.
Entry.320:
Up 7am. Not nearly so cold. About 9.30am Uncle Ida & self went into Filey – saw a military church parade, then walked down the beach esplanade & around the town arriving back 11.15am. was very windy out but enjoyed the walk immensely. Went for

short walk after tea along Seamer & Malton Rd with Uncle. After church when he came back he showed me the family Bible so I took a copy of the family Births Marriages & Deaths. Uncle also showed me some things belonging originally to my Father. He also has some Silk Hdcfs Father sent him. Auntie also said she still has Fancy Work sent to Grandma from Australia. Uncle also told me Great-Grandfather was in Life Guards & was killed when Grandma 3 years old. His name was Smith.

7/10/18 Up 5.45am. Raining. Walked to Filey Stn & train left 7.47am. Travelled via Scarboro, Seamer, Rillington, Malton, Castle Howard, Kirkham Abbey

arriving York 9.30am. Got in Edinburgh train on No14 Platform & left 10.5am travelling via Tollerton, Alne, Thirsk, Northallerton, Croft Spa , Darlington, Durham, Birtley, Low Fell, Newcastle, Killingworth, Morpeth, Alnmouth Junct, Falloden, Chathill, Belford, Beal, Goswick, Scremerston, Tweedmouth, Berwick, Burnmouth, Ayton, Reston Jct, Grants House, Cockburns Path, Innerwick, Dunbar, Prestopans, Inveresk & Portobello arriving Edinburgh almost 4pm. Went & booked bed & breakfast at Cockburn Temperance Hotel near Waverley Stn for 6/6. Then went down Princes St for a walk & bought lettercard & views of Edinburgh & sent a book of views to Mother & a letter card to Ida. Had tea at the YMCA (Sausages & Eggs) costing
Entry.321:
Then went down street again & off to bed 10pm.

Journey up from York is very pretty especially up from Durham & from Berwick northwards. Raining good deal.
Entry.322:
Slept well. Up 7am. had bacon & eggs for breakfast then went to station & got on Aberdeen train leaving 8.15am. Travelled via Turnhouse, Dalmeny, Forth Bridge, North Queensferry, Inverkeithing Aberdour, Kinghorn, Kirkaldy, Sinclairtown, Dysart, Cupar, St Fort, Tay Bridge, Dundee, Broughty Ferry, Monifieth, Carnoustie, Arbroath, Cauldcots, Inverkeilor, Lunan Bay, Montrose, Laurencekirk, Stonehaven, Cove bay, & arrived Aberdeen about noon. Then went & got bed & breakfast at 74 Union St & was stuck up by some big gun for not saluting him?? He had my

name taken but expect nothing more will be heard of it. Had good dinner at a restaurant & then bought views & cards of the place & sent them & those of previous places I was at to Australia. Food seems more plentiful up here. Had good tea at same cafe & after having a shave went to bridge over River Dee by train. Changed my quarters to YMCA during afternoon as I did not like 74 Union St. Just took a drunk Aussie down to Red Cross joint for a bed. He was helpless. Just talking to a bluejacket over on leave from Groningen, Holland. He was on Submarine E17 & she was wrecked on Dutch Coast. They are very

rough in their camp as it is in a pro-German part of Holland. he has only 2 blankets & straw right through the winter. Saw dozens of warships when passing over Forth Bridge, also the Rosyth naval base.
Entry.323:
Up 7.15am the boarded the Glasgow train leaving at 9am. Travelled via Cove Bay, Stonehaven, Fordoun, Marykirk, Crays, Dulton, Bridge of Dun, Auldbar Rd, Forfar, Eassie, Alyth Jct, Coupar Angus, Woodside, Perth, Forgendenny, Auchterarder, Gleneagle, Kinluck, Dunblane, Bridge of Allan, Stirling, Bannockburn, Pleane, Larbert, Greenhill, Sighthill Jct, & St Rollox to Buchanan St Stn Glasgow, arriving about 2pm. Asked an NZ best place to stay & he sent me to the overseas Club in Buchanan

St. They had no rooms left but sent me to Bradfords Temperance Hotel near St Enoch’s Stn where I got a bed for 2/6. Then had good dinner at club for ½ & then went down streets. Bought views of Glasgow & ppcards posted then away. Also bought box of chocolates for Ida. After tea went to Grand Opera at Theatre Royal with another Aussie from Bendigo, but did not enjoy it much. Went to bed about 10pm.
Entry.324:
Up 7am, breakfast at Club for 1/2 - was very good too, then to barber for shave. Went to 

Renfrew by train running practically parallel to Clyde River. Passed en route Fairfield Ship building yards & Harland & Wolfs. Raining all morning. Had lunch at a restaurant about 12 noon then went to Central Stn & got a London train leaving at 1pm. Travelled via Motherwell, Wishaw South, Carluke, Carstairs, Lockerbie, Gretna, Carlisle, Wreay, Penrith, Shap, to Oxenholme. Was told to change at this place for Barrow as train now misses connection at Carnforth so did so. Porters sent me to booking office to get my ticket for Barrow & clerk was so slow that I missed the train. Found would 

not now be able to arrive at Barrow til about 1am so decided to get bed this end for night. No hotels at Oxenholme but they told me to go to Kendal about 3 miles away by train, which I did & got room at County Hotel, which seems a very nice clean place. Went down street for a stroll but too dark & wet to see anything. Kendal was incorporated in 1575 during Queen Elizabeths reign & in 1745 Prince Charlie slept in the town when escaping. An Aussie who came with me to this place from Weymouth told me he was told to out to Forth Bge as Grand

Fleet was there. It must have been the Grand Fleet I saw on Tuesday when going up. There were dozens of British & American warships anchored from Rosyth right down below the ridge.

Continued in new diary.
